title: Cardboard
description: Cardboard, commonly used in packaging and shipping, is highly recyclable when clean and dry.
instructions: Remove all plastic tape, labels, and staples
Flatten boxes : Break down cardboard boxes to save space and make them easier to transport or fit in your recycling bin.
Wet or greasy cardboard (like pizza boxes) can’t be recycled easily. If only part of the box is greasy, tear off the clean part and recycle that.
Sort : Some recycling programs ask you to separate corrugated cardboard (like shipping boxes) from paperboard (like cereal boxes). Check your local guidelines.
Place the cardboard in your curbside recycling bin or take it to a recycling center. Make sure it’s not overflowing or exposed to rain.
Recycling rules can vary by city or country. Some places have special drop-off points or collection days for large amounts of cardboard.

title: Glass
description: Glass containers like bottles and jars can be recycled endlessly without losing purity or quality.
instructions: Rinse thoroughly to remove food or drink residue
Avoid breaking glass—shards are dangerous and hard to sort
Recycle only container glass; keep ceramics and Pyrex out

Do not put the following in your glass recycling:

Drinking glasses
Window glass or mirrors
Pyrex or glass cookware
Light bulbs or fluorescent tubes
Ceramics (e.g. mugs, plates)
Candles in glass holders
These items are made from different types of glass that melt at different temperatures and can contaminate the recycling process

title: Aluminium
description: Aluminium, such as drink cans and foil trays, is one of the most valuable recyclable materials.
instructions: Rinse cans and trays to remove food or drink
Scrunch foil into a ball—this helps sorting machines identify it.
Crush cans to maximize bin space
Recycle only clean aluminium—dirty foil can spoil the batch

title: Plastic
description: Rigid plastics like bottles and containers can be recycled into new packaging, textiles, and more.
instructions: Rinse containers clean
Remove labels, caps, and stickers if possible
Check local guidelines for accepted plastic types (e.g., #1 PET, #2 HDPE)
Lids on or off depending on local guidance

title: Electronics
description: E-waste contains valuable metals and components that can be recovered and reused.
instructions: Remove and recycle batteries separately
Do not attempt to dismantle electronics yourself
Drop off at certified e-waste recycling centers or collection events

title: Food Waste
description: Organic food scraps can be composted to enrich soil and reduce landfill waste.
instructions: Separate food from any packaging
Avoid adding meat, dairy, or oily foods unless your compost system allows it
Use a compost bin or municipal food waste collection

title: Metal
description: Scrap metal, including steel and copper, can be recycled into new construction materials and tools.
instructions: Clean off any paint or chemicals
Sort metals by type if possible (e.g., steel vs. copper)
Take large or mixed metal items to a scrap yard or recycling center

title: Textiles
description: Old clothes, linens, and fabrics can be reused or recycled into insulation, rags, or new textiles.
instructions: Remove non-fabric parts like buttons or zippers if possible
Ensure items are clean and dry
Donate wearable items; recycle damaged ones through textile banks

title: Wood
description: Untreated wood can be chipped and reused in landscaping or composting.
instructions: Remove nails, screws, and finishes
Cut into manageable pieces
Recycle untreated wood only—treated wood may release toxins

title: Flexible Plastics
description: Soft plastics like bags and wrappers can be recycled at special collection points.
instructions: Clean and dry before recycling
Do not include mixed-material packaging (e.g., chip bags)
Drop off at designated supermarket or recycling center bins
